TravelTriangle > Blog > Temples > 14 Must Visit Temples in Visakhapatnam for a Spiritual Experience 14 Must Visit Temples in Visakhapatnam for a Spiritual Experience .. SHARES Updated Date: 21 February 2025 Visakhapatnam, Vizag, or Waltair is the financial capital of Andhra Pradesh. It is the administrative headquarters of Visakhapatnam district and state headquarters of the Indian Coast Guard.Visakhapatnam is present amid the Eastern Ghats on the Bay of Bengal coastline. The beaches, hills, and valleys make it the most sought-after tourist spot. While visiting, go for darshan at some of the grand temples in Visakhapatnam. Most of the famous temples are within city-limit, while others located a few miles away are reachable via vehicles. Table Of Content 14 Most Famous Temples In Visakhapatnam Here is the Visakhapatnam temple list. All of these temples have an essence of spirituality exuding from every nook.  Varaha Lakshmi Narasimha Temple Kanaka Maha Lakshmi Temple Sampath Vinayagar Temple Kala Bhairava Temple  Sai Baba Temple Venkateswara Swamy Temple Brahmalingeshwara Temple Sri Kanaka Mahalakshmi Temple AshtaLakshmi Temple Somalingeshwara Swamy Temple Ramadri Temple ISKCON Temple  Kailasagiri Kali Temple 1. Varaha Lakshmi Narasimha Temple Varaha Lakshmi Narasimha temple or Simhachalam Temple Vizag is on Simhachalam hill, 300m above sea level. The temple architecture is a combination of Kalinga/Odishan, Cholas, and Chalukyas. Although most temples are East facing, this one faces the West. Swami Pushkarini tank is near the temple while the Gangadhara tank is at the bottom of the hill. Simhachalam Temple Vizag is dedicated to Lord Vishnu in the form of Lord Varaha Narasimha. According to the legend (thirty-two chapters), Lord Vishnu appeared in non-human form. He had boar’s head, human being’s torso, and lion’s tail when he saved his devotee, Prahlad. Prahlad’s father, Hiranyakashipu was defeatless because of his received boon — no human form could kill him. Timings: 4:00 AM to 9:00 PM (Public Holidays – Timing might differ) Specialty: Except on Akshaya Tritiya, every day, Lord Varaha Narasimha is covered with sandalwood paste. Address: Simhachalam Road, Simhachalam, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh South Weekend Holiday Packages On TravelTriangle Delightful South Weekend Tour 3D/2N Package @ Rs 4,999 Plan your trip today! EMI option available. Book Now See more at TRAVELTRIANGLE.COM Visit Website 2. Kanaka MahaLakshmi Temple Kanaka MahaLakshmi Temple originally was located inside Burujupeta Fort. Visakha kings were attacked, when enemies destroyed the temple and dropped the deity into a well. Goddess Laxmi appeared in her devotees’ dreams, mentioning her desire for a roofless temple. In 1907, Kanaka MahaLakshmi Temple, one of the most famous temples in Visakhapatnam, was completed. This roofless temple was made at Burujupeta in One Town area, where devotees themselves offer prayer. The well is filled with idols of Ashta Lakshmis. According to Sthala Puranam, its location was in the middle of the road. When the temple was shifted to a corner, residents died of the plague. Again the temple was returned to the original position. Soon plague epidemic vanished, allowing people to lead their healthy lives. People believe that the Goddess removes devotees’ problems and fulfills* their wishes. Timings: Open 24 hours Specialty: “Margasira Masotsavamulu” (November 30 to December 29). Address: Town Kotha Road, Burujupeta, Chengal Rao Peta, Port Area, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh 3. Sampath Vinayagar Temple  Sampath Vinayagar Temple, one of the famous temples in Vizag, draws local devotees. T. S. Selvaganesan, T. S. Rajeswaran, and late S.G. Sambandan built this temple for themselves. The temple, located in S.G. Sambandan and Co. complex in Asilmetta, was completed in 1962. This temple dedicated to Lord Ganapati attracted fishermen who daily prayed before leaving for work. In 1967, Kanchi Peetadhipathi and Chandrasekharendra Saraswati commenced Ganapati Yantra within this temple. Admiral Krishnan, in charge of Eastern Naval, broke 1001 coconuts in this auspicious temple. This was after Vizag was saved from the dangerous Pakistani Submarine Ghazi attack in December 1971. Timings: Open 24 hours Specialty: Ganesh Chaturthi Address: 10-1-33 Waltair Appliance, road, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh  4. Kala Bhairava Temple Kalabhairava temple in Vizag, also called Sri Kala Bhairava Swamy Temple, is surrounded by forests of Simhachalam. This Bhairava corner on Sontyam Road is 4 km from Adivivaram and 8 km from Simhachalam. Kalabhairava temple in Vizag is famous ever since Lord Kala Bhairava Swamy self-manifested. Devotees overcome all obstructions and offer prayers on Amavasya. Timings: 7:00 AM to 7:00 PM Specialty: Karthika Masam and Maha Shivaratri. Address: Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh 5. Sai Baba Temple Sai Baba temple at Chinna Waltair is one of the most auspicious temples in Vizag. On 9th February 1977, Bhoomi Pooja of this temple was conducted. Since 18th March 1993, devotees of Sai Baba have been organizing prayer meetings. They worship the 5.5 feet tall idol of Sri Sai Baba located on the first floor. Sai Baba complex has Visakhapatnam temple list dedicated to Gods and Goddesses worshipped in Southern India. Names include Ganapati, Vishakeswara (Shiva), Parvati Devi, Dattatreya, Rama, Hanuman, Sanishwara, Suryanarayana, Swamy Aiyappa, Dhuni, and Dwarakamai. Timings: 5:15 AM to 8:30 PM Specialty: Kakad Aarti on opening while Shej Aarti before closing Address: East Point Colony, Chinna Waltair, Pedda Waltair, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh 6. Venkateswara Swamy Temple Venkateswara Swamy Temple, one of the temples in Vizag, draws devotees from across the nation. It is located on the Srungamani Hill, where people believe Garuda seated Lord Venkateswara and Lakshmi. Krishana Bhupaluda, King of East Godavari District, constructed it in the 16th century AD. Ramanuja declared the temple as one of the 108 sacred Vaishnava Abhimana Kshethrams. After that, Venkateswara Swamy Temple is one of the most famous temples in Vizag. The name of this temple has been mentioned in the Brahmavaivartha Puranam (Garudachala Mahatmayam). According to the legend, the deity of Lord Venkateswara was recovered from under the rocks. Other names of the same temple are Swayambhoo and Upamaka. Timings: 6:00 AM to 12:30 PM, 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM Specialty: Lord Venkateswara grants the wishes of devotees. Address: Beach Road, Port Are, Near Post Office, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh 7. Brahmalingeshwara Temple With historical significance attached to itself, Brahmalingeshwara Temple is a famous temple in Vizag that attracts several hundreds of devotees all year round. Constructed under the command of the Chola Kings back in the day, this temple is believed to have been built by the Gods themselves. After years of standing proudly, the temple has now gone under renovation and a new face is ready to be exposed to the world. Exuding old world charm, this temple is home to the Lord Brahma Lingam. It is believed that this was the spot where the Lord was very pleased with Bali Chakravarthi’s penance for Lord Shiva. Hence, this is how the temple got its ame. It is also famous for the holy river Varahi that flows from north to south for a short while. Timings: 4:00 AM to 9:00 PM Specialty: The “Sivaratri” festival is celebrated grandly every year. Address: Balighattam, Visakhapatnam 8. Sri Kanaka Mahalakshmi Temple Sitting in Buruju Peta, Sri Kanaka Mahalakshmi Temple is a famous temple in Vizag among the locals and tourists alike. The deity, Sri Kanaka Mahalakshmi Ammaavaru, is believed to be the family deity of the Royal families of Visakhapatnam. The legend says that the statue of this Goddess was unearthed from a nearby well and established at the spot of the temple back in the year 1912. There are many beliefs attached to the placement of this idol. Once, the authorities shifted the idol to make space for road extensions. As a result, it is believed that the plague took place in the city. Everything went back to normal once the idol was replaced back to the center of the road. Timings: Open 24 hours Specialty: The idol has many beliefs attached such as the placement of the statue affects the health of the city. Address: Kanaka MahaLaxmi Temple, Burujupeta, Chengal Rao Peta, Port Area, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh 9. AshtaLakshmi Temple Disclaimer: The image is for representation purposes only. This temple is believed to be the sea abode for Lord Narayana aka Maha Vishnu and also the birthplace of Goddess Laxmi. Several hundreds of devotees and believers are seen visiting the AshtaLakshmi Temple. The stunning sculptures of graceful Goddess Laxmi with a veena and Lord Srimannarayan leaves spectators in awe of the craftsmanship. There are also mini temples of Bala Subramanyam, Bala Ganpati, and Mangala Gowri sitting on either side of the main temple. Timings: 6:00 AM – 12:00 PM, 5:00 PM – 9:00 PM Specialty: There are Nine Karma Sakshis that ensures happiness and health of the visitors. Address: Kommadi Rd, Revallapalem, Bakkannapalem, Madhurawada, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh 10. Somalingeshwara Swamy Temple Disclaimer: The image is for representation purposes only. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, Somalingeshwara Swamy Temple has earned its fame by virtue of the grand celebrations of the Mahashivratri Festival. A large number of devotees and believers come together to celebrate this festival at the temple. Initially, the temple was named as the Appikonda Temple by the fishermen that reside in the village. It is believed that the villagers were offered this piece of land back in the 12th century. This village is slowly attracting tourists by virtue of the temple. Timings: 7:00 AM – 4:00 PM, 6:00 PM – 9:00 PM Specialty: The Mahashivtratri festival is the biggest hit of this temple. Address: Bangarammapalem, Visakhapatnam 11. Ramadri Temple Disclaimer: The image is for representation purposes only. Located a few kilometers from the main city of Visakhapatnam, Ramadri Temple can be seen sitting proudly on the Bheemili Beach road. This temple earned its fame when a 40 feet tall statue of Lord Hanuman was constructed. This is the major highlight of the temple and attracts several visitors, including locals and tourists both. The statue of Hanuman is white in color and has some beautiful intricate lines carved on it. Handled by World Teacher Trust, the statue stands tall atop a hill that offers some impressive views of the Bay of Bengal. Timings: NA Specialty: The statue of Lord Hanuman in this temple is around 40 feet tall. Address: Bheemili, Visakhapatnam 12. ISKCON Temple – Sagar Nagar ISKCON Temple was founded back in 1996 in New York City by the respected A.C. Bhakti Vedanta Swami Prabhudeva, and now has spread all across the globe. One of its branches can be seen in Visakhapatnam. ISKCON Temple is dedicated to Lord Krishna and Goddess Radha. Started as a part of the ‘Hare Krishna’ movement, the idea behind the establishment of this temple was to spread awareness about the writings of holy Bhagwat Geeta. In ISKCON Visakhapatnam, you can also find deities of Sri Jagannatha Baladeva Subhadra and Sri Lakshmi Narasimha Devi. Bhajans, Kirtanas, Srimad Bhagvatam courses, seminar classes, and much more is hosted at this temple. Timings: 7:30 AM – 12:30 PM, 4:00 PM – 8:30 PM Specialty: The temple provides lunch services for government schools in the nearby sectors. Address: Beach Road, Hare Krishna Land, Sagar Nagar, Rushikonda, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh 13. Kailasagiri Just like Ramadri is abode to a massive statue of Lord Hanuman, Kailasagiri is home to the snow-white colored statues of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati. Established under the command of Visakhapatnam Urban Development Authority aka VUDA, this place of worship has been declared as a plastic free zone. Apart from the humongous statue of the god and the goddess, there is also a lush green park that surrounds the deity that is spread over approximately 150 hectares of land. The variety of flowers, trees, and plants leave one in awe. Constructed with marble, the statue is the highlight of this spot. Timings: 10:00 AM – 8:00 PM Specialty: The huge statue of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati constructed with marble. Address: HillTop Rd, Kailasagiri, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh 14. Kali Temple Constructed back in the year 1984, Kali Temple is not your basic temple. Adorning modern style architecture from the outside, this temple is home to tall pillars and intriguing structure that manages to attract tourists and locals alike. The skeletal structure of this temple is built using bamboo and it was then reinforced with cement and concrete. The temple has withstood various calamities. The design was made by A. Joseph from the Department of Zoology in AU. It took two years to complete this beautiful temple and now is home to Goddess Kali as well as Lord Shiva and the Lingam that is made out of a single stone. Timings: 6:00 AM – 12:00 PM, 4:00 PM – 8:00 PM Specialty: The architecture of this traditional temple is actually quite modern! Address: Bus Stop, Beside Kali Mata Temple, near Rk beach, Pandurangapuram, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh Local residents flock to various temples in Visakhapatnam, located within the Vizag city and Visakhapatnam district. These Holy Shrines are extremely auspicious destinations, primarily because Gods and Goddess protect their devotees. Plan a trip to Andhra Pradesh and make sure you visit them. Frequently Asked Questions About Temples In Visakhapatnam What are the other special sight-seeing spots in Vizag? After visiting temples in Visakhapatnam, you might find time for other sight-seeing activities. You can check out the INS Kurusura Submarine Museum in Vizag. This was submerged during the Indo-Pakistan War in 1971. How safe is it to swim in the sea at Visakhapatnam beaches? Vizag has many beaches (Yarada Beach, Rishikonda Beach, Rama Krishna Beach, and others). These beaches are covered with sand and look calm. But, underneath the water, there are huge boulders that are dangerous for swimming in the sea. Only in the winter season when the sea is relatively calm, swim only in the Yarada Beach. What to purchase in and around Visakhapatnam? Travel to picturesque Araku Valley by taking a train or bus. Near the Boro Cave, you can purchase roasted coffee beans and spices that are harvested locally. Looking To Book A Holiday Package?
